dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Their total assets under management still hit 7.6 trillion US dollars in 2017, which is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Their total assets under management still hit seven point six trillion U S dollars in twenty seventeen, which is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report, titled The rising attractiveness of alternative asset classes for Sovereign Wealth Funds, finds that, despite SWFs facing adverse conditions since 2014 when asset growth began to stall as a result of falling oil prices, total assets under management still grew to US$7.4 trillion in 2016, albeit at a slower pace than prior years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's even though, um, growth had been stalling since 2015 because of falling oil prices. They were under a lot of pressure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's even though, um, growth had been stalling since twenty fifteen because of falling oil prices. They were under a lot of pressure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report, titled The rising attractiveness of alternative asset classes for Sovereign Wealth Funds, finds that, despite SWFs facing adverse conditions since 2014 when asset growth began to stall as a result of falling oil prices, total assets under management still grew to US$7.4 trillion in 2016, albeit at a slower pace than prior years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so they're really broadening their strategies now—PwC expects that growth rate to pick up again as they diversify.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so they're really broadening their strategies now-PwC expects that growth rate to pick up again as they diversify.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pressure felt since 2014 is driving SWFs to broaden their investment strategies and PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years as SWFs invest in non-fossil sources and diversify their portfolios to include alternative investments to enhance returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, like moving away from traditional stuff. Did you see the drop in fixed income? Government bonds went from 42% down to 31%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, like moving away from traditional stuff. Did you see the drop in fixed income? Government bonds went from forty two percent down to thirty one percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: SWF investment into fixed income instruments such as government bonds has dropped from a peak of 40% in 2013 to 30% in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a huge shift. And they're looking at alternatives for better returns, even with the risks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a huge shift. And they're looking at alternatives for better returns, even with the risks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pressure felt since 2014 is driving SWFs to broaden their investment strategies and PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years as SWFs invest in non-fossil sources and diversify their portfolios to include alternative investments to enhance returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Speaking of risks, illiquidity is a big one for most alternatives, though gold is an exception—super liquid, protects against market corrections.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Speaking of risks, illiquidity is a big one for most alternatives, though gold is an exception-super liquid, protects against market corrections.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report notes that including certain alternative asset classes is not without risks as the majority of alternatives are highly illiquid. An exception is gold, which has one of the highest rates of daily volumes exchanged and can provide protection against short and medium term market corrections.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: William Jackson-Moore from PwC mentioned that too—alternatives can offer diversification, inflation hedging, all that good stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: William Jackson-Moore from PwC mentioned that too-alternatives can offer diversification, inflation hedging, all that good stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We expect alternatives to be prominent in SWF portfolios in the future as they can offer increased diversification, principal protection, a hedge against inflation, and an increase in portfolio performance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But he also warned about getting the allocation strategy right, you know? Illiquidity, complexity—it's not simple.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But he also warned about getting the allocation strategy right, you know? Illiquidity, complexity-it's not simple.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That being said, finding the right allocation strategy for these asset classes is crucial as including certain alternatives might introduce a new set of risks such as illiquidity, complexity, and cyclicality.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure, continuous monitoring is key. But overall, seems like the benefits outweigh the costs if they're smart about it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure, continuous monitoring is key. But overall, seems like the benefits outweigh the costs if they're smart about it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: SWFs should keep in mind the need for continuous monitoring of their portfolios and their investments and reallocate their capital to reflect economic developments. Overall though, the benefits seem to outweigh the costs, as the varied nature of alternatives provides SWFs with the ability to select an asset class specific to their investment needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Tailoring to specific needs—that flexibility is huge for sovereign wealth funds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Tailoring to specific needs-that flexibility is huge for sovereign wealth funds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overall though, the benefits seem to outweigh the costs, as the varied nature of alternatives provides SWFs with the ability to select an asset class specific to their investment needs.

Their total assets under management still hit 7.6 trillion US dollars in 2017, which is just staggering.
HostB: Yeah, and that's even though, um, growth had been stalling since 2015 because of falling oil prices. They were under a lot of pressure.
HostA: Right, so they’re really broadening their strategies now—PwC expects that growth rate to pick up again as they diversify.
HostB: Exactly, like moving away from traditional stuff. Did you see the drop in fixed income? Government bonds went from 42% down to 31%.
HostA: Yeah, that’s a huge shift. And they’re looking at alternatives for better returns, even with the risks.
HostB: Speaking of risks, illiquidity is a big one for most alternatives, though gold is an exception—super liquid, protects against market corrections.
HostA: William Jackson-Moore from PwC mentioned that too—alternatives can offer diversification, inflation hedging, all that good stuff.
HostB: But he also warned about getting the allocation strategy right, you know? Illiquidity, complexity—it’s not simple.
HostA: For sure, continuous monitoring is key. But overall, seems like the benefits outweigh the costs if they’re smart about it.
HostB: Absolutely. Tailoring to specific needs—that flexibility is huge for sovereign wealth funds.
